results.title: Death of a nation: the Timor conspiracy
results.creator_credit: David Munro and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description: Written and presented by famed Australian journalist, John Pilger, this confronting documentary looks at the history of Indonesia’s occupation of East Timor. Since the 1975 invasion of this tiny island, the Indonesian military government has enacted a policy of genocide which has resulted in over 200,000 deaths and the attempted dismantling of the Timorese language, culture and identity. Much of this documentary was filmed undercover since, as the film makes vividly clear, one of the means by which the Indonenesian government has used to legitimise the occupation is through a blanket censoring of media images about and from East Timor. One of the most chilling aspects of this documentary is the evidence presented of the tacit assistance the governments of Australia, Great Britain and the United States have given to the invasion and occupation, an occupation which has seen some of the most barbaric human rights abuses of the twentieth century. The video includes interviews with former Western ambassadors to Indonesia; survivors of torture; and with FRETELIN guerrilla fighters who are still resisting the Indonesians without the assistance of any outside aid.

results.title: The Panama deception
results.creator_credit: Barbara Trent, David Kasper, Joanne Doroshow, Nico Panigutti and Empowerment Project
results.brief_description: In December 1989, the United States military invaded Panama on the pretext of “restoring democracy” and arresting the President, Manuel Noriega, who had been indicted by the US Supreme Court on drug trafficking charges. This cooly argued and well-researched documentary argues that the invasion of Panama was a cold-blooded exercise, initiated by President George Bush, in which the United States destroyed a country’s infrastructure, and killed over 3,000 people, in order to ensure their dominance in Central American politics and to ensure control of the Panama Canal well into the 21st Century. “The Panama Deception” investigates the links between the United States military, international drug-trafficking and illegal arms dealings. The film also exposes the cynical manipulation of the media by the US Government. The collaboration of the media guaranteed the successful selling of the invasion to the US public. Two years on from the invasion which the United Nations called illegal, refugees still live in tents in Panama; the incidents of mass-murder and incaceration remain uninvestigated and democracy still has not been “restored” by the US but the Americans now have guaranteed military control of the Panama Canal. Winner of Best Documentary Feature at the 1993 Academy Awards. Music by Sting and Jackson Browne. Narrated by Elisabeth Montgomery.

results.title: The Merchant of Venice
results.creator_credit: John Sichel, Cecil Clarke and Associated Television
results.brief_description: Laurence Olivier and Joan Plowright head the cast of The National Theatre Company’s presentation of Jonathan Miller’s brilliant stage production of the Merchant of Venice. This particular Shakespeare production is set in Venice in the 1880’s and includes a musical score by Carl Davies. The focus is on the central character of Shylock, the Jew, played powerfully and unusually sympathetically by Laurence Olivier. The story involves a young Venetian Antonio (Anthony Nichols) who borrows money from Shylock on the security of a pound of flesh. On default of his bond a trial takes place and the heroine Portia (Joan Plowright) pleads in Antonio’s defence. Whilst the romantic comedy aspects of the play are retained, there is a heightened sense of drama throughout this production with the trial scene making a forceful climax. The cast also includes Jeremy Brett as Bassanio and Michael Jayston as Gratiano.

results.title: The Piano
results.creator_credit: Jane Campion, Jan Chapman, CiBy 2000 and Saddleback Productions
results.brief_description: Jane Campion’s fourth feature is a visually sumptuous and tactile tale of adultery set during the early European colonisation of New Zealand, with Harvey Keitel daringly cast in the role of a passionately romantic lover and Holly Hunter as a woman physically unable to articulate her feelings. Ada McGrath (Hunter) can hear and communicates in sign language through her young daughter, Fiona (Anna Paquin), but she can’t talk. Apart from her child, Ada’s most treasured possession is her piano. She marries a man she’s never met, a pioneer settler (Sam Neill) in New Zealand. The marriage starts badly when Neill refuses to transport Ada’s piano to his settlement. Later, he allows George Baines (Keitel), who has ‘gone native’ to have the piano. Baines then offers to return the piano to Ada - if she gives him piano lessons. These lessons become stages in an increasingly erotic courtship. Campion unfolds this striking story boldly with flashes of unexpected humour. The settlement is chilly, muddy and rainswept, a place where civilisation is barely making an impact. Hunter played solo piano and acted as piano coach on this production. Paquin became one of the youngest actors to receive an Academy Award for her performance. Cast also includes Kerry Walker, Genevieve Lemon.

results.title: A Portrait of the artist as a young man
results.creator_credit: Joseph Strick and Ulysses Film Production
results.brief_description: This magnificent adaption of James Joyce’s autobiographical novel is a faithful portrait of the young author and his coming-of-age. It portrays Stephen Dedalus and his Irish Catholic upbringing, his confrontation with the tyranny of the Church and his sexual guilt and frustration which start him on the path of rebellion. The young artist chooses lonely exile in his search for freedom and truth. Starring Bosco Hogan, T.P. McKenna and John Gielgud.

results.title: Ulysses
results.creator_credit: Joseph Strick, Continental and Walter Reade
results.brief_description: Portrays a stream-of-consciousness in a day in the life of Leopold Bloom, Molly Bloom and Stephen Dedalus (the hero of Joyce’s earlier biographical novel, “A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man”). Bloom is an ordinary man; a Jew whose odyssey through the streets of turn-of-the-century Dublin leads him through trails that parallel his classic prototype, Ulysses on his epic journey home. Molly is his voluptuous, delightfully earthy wife whose infidelity is a major burden to Bloom. The intimacy of Joyce’s language was without precedent in literature, and its flashbacks, dream episodes, sounds and visual montages translate freely into the language of cinema. Starring Milo O’Shea and Barbara Jefford.

results.title: The Phantom of liberty = La Fantome de la liberte
results.creator_credit: Luis Bunuel, Serge Silberman and Greenwich Films
results.brief_description: This is Bunuel’s very personal version of La Ronde, and in eight sketches - each representing a different aspect of hypocrisy - he creates a succession of dazzling moments. The sketches use every type of comedy: there is a interval of French farce with slamming bedroom doors, two trenchantly black jokes about cancer and mass murder and a piece of pure lunesco. Each sketch has its point to make and its own authority figures to be lampooned. This is a delightful and hilarious Bunuelian masterpiece. French dialogue with English subtitles.

results.title: The Dead
results.creator_credit: John Huston, Chris Sievernich, Wieland Schulz-Keil, Channel Four, Delta Films, Liffey Films, Vestron Pictures and Zenith
results.brief_description: It is January 6, 1904, on a snowy night in Dublin; a festive night at the Morkan house, as Miss Kate, Miss Julia and their niece Mary Jane prepare for their annual party. In this his last film, John Huston, captures the wonderful mix of comedy and quiet tragedy portrayed in James Joyce’s short stroy from “The Dubliners”. As the evening progresses, the characters subtly betray their secret lives, culminating in the moment when Gabriel, the calm observer, learns a secret that will change his life forever. A beautiful, eloquent film.

results.title: Smash palace
results.creator_credit: Roger Donaldson, Aardvark Films and New Zealand Film Commission
results.brief_description: Smash Palace is a remarkable drama about a marital breakup which erupts into an impulsive kidnapping of a child by the father, and a totally credible escalation to the brink of tragedy. Bruno Lawrence and Anna Jemison play the estranged couple in strong performances. Filmed amongst a vast junk-yard of cars, Donaldson’s direction is economical and enthralling, capturing the tension that goes beneath the surface of this all too real drama.

results.title: Patrick
results.creator_credit: Richard Franklin, Antony Ginnane, Australian International Film Corporation and IFM Films
results.brief_description: Patrick, having murdered his mother and her lover, has become a polyplegic, pre-oedipal, psychotic lump. He has telekinetic powers, fancies his nurse and is hostile to his doctor. This is an entertaining mix of black humour and suspense with a few shocks. Cast includes Susan Penhaligon, Robert Helpmann and Rod Mullinar.
